tit.e: The Omuro School of the Shingon Sect
The Omuro School of the Shingon Sect

sen.j: 真言宗御室派（しんごんしゅうおむろは）は、日本における真言系仏教宗派のひとつで、古義真言宗に属する。
sen.e: Omuro School of Shingon ("True Word") Sect is one of Shingon Sect schools in Japan and belongs to Kogi (old) Shingon Sect.
The Omuro School of the Shingon ("True Word") sect is one of the Shingon sect schools in Japan and belongs to the Kogi (old) Shingon sect.
The Omuro School of the Shingon ("True Word") sect is one of the Shingon sect schools in Japan and belongs to the Kogi (old) Shingon sect.

sen.j: 総本山は仁和寺。
sen.e: Its Sohonzan (grand head temple) is Ninna-ji Temple.
Its Sohonzan (grand head temple) is Ninna-ji Temple.
Its Sohonzan (grand head temple) is Ninna-ji Temple.

sen.j: 宗祖 弘法大師空海
sen.e: The founder of the sect: Kobo daishi, Kukai

The founder of the school: Cloistered Emperor Kanpyo (Emperor Uda)

sen.j: 桜に引両
sen.e: Cherry blossoms with Hikiryo (a design considered to stand for good luck, consisting of a circle and one or a few parallel lines dawn inside of it)

sen.j: 沿革
sen.e: Its history
Its history
History

sen.j: 真言宗御室派の歴史は仁和寺の開創に始まる。
sen.e: The history of the Omuro School of Shingon Sect began when Ninna-ji Temple was founded.
The history of the Omuro School of the Shingon sect began with the establishment of Ninna-ji Temple.
The history of the Omuro School of the Shingon sect began with the establishment of Ninna-ji Temple.

sen.j: 真言宗の事相の流派「広沢流」の本拠として発展した。
sen.e: This temple developed as the headquarters of the Hirosawa-ryu school (one of the two schools in Kogi Shingon Sect), which valued Jiso (the practical aspects of esoteric Buddhism, including rituals, incantation, and prayer).
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外処理（1）
sen.e: This temple developed as the headquarters of the Hirosawa-ryu school (one of the two schools in the Kogi Shingon sect), which valued Jiso (the practical aspects of Esoteric Buddhism, including rituals, incantations and prayers).

This temple developed as the headquarters of the Hirosawa school (one of the two schools in the Kogi Shingon sect), which valued Jiso (the practical aspects of Esoteric Buddhism, including rituals, incantations and prayers).

sen.j: 仁和寺門跡に2世性信入道親王（大御室）が就任されて以降、江戸時代末期まで門跡には法親王（皇族）を迎えた。
sen.e: Since Nyudo Shinno (priestly Imperial Prince) Shoshin (Omuro) took the post of its second Monzeki (chief priest), imperial family members took this post in generations towards the end of the Edo period.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外処理（2）「門跡」の定義ですが、宗派の伝統を受け継いだものという意味で使われていたようですが、ここでは、後継者すなわち、住持という意味で訳しています。
sen.e: Since Nyudo Shinno (priestly Imperial Prince) Shoshin (Omuro) took the post as its second Monzeki (chief priest), over succeeding generations toward the end of the Edo period, members of the Imperial Family took this post as well.

Since Nyudo Shinno (priestly Imperial Prince) Shoshin (Omuro) took the post as its second Monzeki (chief priest), over succeeding generations toward the end of the Edo period, members of the Imperial Family took this post as well.

sen.j: 1167年（仁安2年）5世覚性入道親王（紫金台寺御室）が綱所の印璽を下賜され、日本総法務に任ぜられると諸宗格山を支配し、日本仏教界に君臨した。
sen.e: Since Nyudo Shinno Kakusho (Shikondai-ji omuro), who was its fifth chief priest, was designated as "Nihon sohomu", the head of Kosho (Office of Priests), by being awarded an Inji (imperial seal) in 1167, it put under the umbrella many temples of different sects and vehicles, practically leading the Japanese Buddhist society.
sen.cmt: 「諸宗格山」ですが、諸宗がどれほどの範囲可が分かりません。文字通りに訳しています。
sen.e: Since Nyudo Shinno Kakusho (Shikondai-ji omuro), who was its fifth chief priest, was designated as "Nihon sohomu," or the head of Kosho (Office of Priests), by being awarded an Inji (imperial seal) in 1167, it brought under its umbrella many temples of different sects and vehicles, and thus practically led the Japanese Buddhist society.

Since Nyudo Shinno Kakusho (Shikondai-ji omuro), who was its fifth chief priest, was designated as Nihon sohomu, or the head of Kosho (Office of Priests), by being awarded an Inji (imperial seal) in 1167, it brought under its umbrella many temples of different sects and vehicles, and thus practically led the Japanese Buddhist society.

sen.j: 塔頭寺院・子院が60余を数えた時期もあった。
sen.e: At its best, it reigned more than sixty tatchu (minor) and branch temples.
At its peak, it reigned over more than 60 tatchu (minor temples) and branch temples.
At its peak, it reigned over more than 60 tatchu (sub-temples) and branch temples.

sen.j: 中世に入ると、応仁の乱のときに仁和寺は全焼して、衰退した。
sen.e: In the medieval period, however, the temple was entirely destroyed by fire in the Onin war and lost its power.
However, during the medieval period the temple was entirely destroyed by fire in the Onin War and therefore lost its power.
However, during the medieval period the temple was entirely destroyed by fire in the Onin War and therefore lost its power.

sen.j: 戦国期以降は足利氏・織田氏・豊臣氏が復興に努めたが、本格的な再興には至らなかった。
sen.e: Although the Achikaga, Oda, and Toyotomi clans attempted to restore it during and after the Sengoku period (period of warring states), it couldn't be revived in full.
Although the Achikaga, Oda and Toyotomi clans attempted to restore it during and after the Sengoku (Warring States) period, it couldn't be fully revived.
Although the Ashikaga, Oda and Toyotomi clans attempted to restore it during and after the Sengoku Period (Period of Warring States), it couldn't be fully revived.

sen.j: 江戸時代に入り、江戸幕府による資金援助があり、現在地に堂塔の再建がなり、再興を果たした。
sen.e: However, financially supported by the Edo bakufu during the Edo period, it was fully restored to the current state; the halls and pagodas we see today were built around this time.
However, financially supported by the Edo bakufu during the Edo period, it was fully restored to its current state; the halls and pagodas we see today were built in or around that time.

However, financially supported by the Edo bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) during the Edo period, it was fully restored to its current state; the halls and pagodas we see today were built in or around that time.

sen.j: 明治維新のときに、勅命により、30世純仁（楞厳定院御室）が還俗した。
sen.e: In Meiji Restoration, its thirtieth chief priest, Sumihito (Ryogenjyoin omuro), became a layman at an imperial order.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外処理（1）「楞厳定院御室」の読みが不明
sen.e: In the Meiji Restoration, its thirtieth chief priest, Sumihito (Ryogenjyoin omuro), became a layman by imperial order.
In the Meiji Restoration, its thirtieth chief priest, Sumihito (Ryogenjoin omuro), became a layman by imperial order.

sen.j: 改称した小松宮彰仁親王が1883年（明治17年）に仁和会を組織して仁和寺の復興に尽力した。
sen.e: Under his new secular name, Imperial Prince Komatsunomiya Akihito worked hard to restore the temple by founding an organization called Ninnakai in 1883.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外処理（2）
sen.e: Under his new secular name, Imperial Prince Komatsunomiya Akihito worked hard to restore the temple by founding an organization called Ninnakai in 1883.
Under his new secular name, Imperial Prince Komatsunomiya Akihito worked hard to restore the temple by founding an organization called Ninnakai in 1883.

sen.j: 31世以降、門跡に皇族を迎えることは無くなった。
sen.e: Since its thirty-first monzeki, it stopped accepting imperial family members as its chief priest.
Since its thirty-first monzeki, it had stopped accepting members of the Imperial Family as chief priests.
Since its thirty-first monzeki, it had stopped accepting members of the Imperial Family as chief priests.

sen.j: 東寺の傘下を出入をしたが1900年（明治33）年、独立して真言宗御室派を公称。
sen.e: Although it temporarily came under the umbrella of To-ji Temple ("East Temple", the grand headquarters of Toji Shingon Sect, also founded by Kukai), it broke away from it in 1900 and officially called itself "Omuro School of Shingon Sect".

Although it temporarily came under the umbrella of To-ji Temple ("East Temple," the grand headquarters of the Toji Shingon sect, also founded by Kukai), it broke away from it in 1900 and officially called itself the "Omuro School of the Shingon Sect."

Although it temporarily came under the umbrella of To-ji Temple ("East Temple," the grand headquarters of the Toji Shingon sect, also founded by Kukai), it broke away from it in 1900 and officially called itself the Omuro School of the Shingon Sect.

sen.j: 派を廃し,1926年（大正16年）に金剛峯寺・大覚寺とともに古義真言宗を称した。
sen.e: It abandoned its status as a school of Shingon Sect; in 1926, it called itself "Kogi Shingon Sect", along with Kongobu-ji and Daikaku-ji Temples.
It abandoned its status as a school of the Shingon sect; in 1926, it called itself the "Kogi Shingon" sect, along with Kongobu-ji and Daikaku-ji temples.
It abandoned its status as a school of the Shingon sect; in 1926, it called itself the Kogi Shingon sect, along with Kongobu-ji and Daikaku-ji temples.

sen.j: 第二次世界大戦のさなか、日本政府の宗教政策により、真言宗の古義・新義両派を合同して大真言宗になったが、戦後に独立し、1946年（昭和21年）、真言宗御室派となった。
sen.e: During the World War II, the Japanese government's religious policy forced Kogi (old) and Singi (new) Shingon Sects to be integrated into Dai Shingon (literally, "Large Shingon"), but after the war, it went independent and named itself "Omuro School of Shingon Sect" in 1946.

During World War II, the Japanese government's policy on religion forced Kogi (old) and Singi (new) Shingon sects to be integrated into Dai Shingon (literally, "Large Shingon"), but in 1946, after the war it became independent and began referring to itself as the "Omuro School of the Shingon Sect."

During World War II, the Japanese government's policy on religion forced Kogi (old) and Singi (new) Shingon sects to be integrated into Dai Shingon (literally, "Large Shingon"), but in 1946, after the war it became independent and began referring to itself as the Omuro School of the Shingon Sect.

sen.j: 1級 大僧正
sen.e: First rank: Dai (high) sojo (the highest ranking Buddhist priest position, further divided into three ranks, "dai" (high), "chu" (middle), and "sho" (low), each of which is further separated into 'senior' and 'junior' ("gon"))
sen.cmt: 「僧正」の訳には、archibishopとすることもできますが、そうすると、律師を特定することができず、結局、ここでは、僧階のイメージが訳出できれば良いものと判断し、規則的にランク付けされている僧階をできるだけ、英語で表現しました。
sen.e: First rank: Dai (high) sojo (the highest-ranking Buddhist priest position, further divided into three ranks, "dai" (high), "chu" (middle) and "sho" (low), each of which is further separated into 'senior' and 'junior' ("gon"))

First rank: Dai (high) sojo (the highest-ranking Buddhist priest position, further divided into three ranks, "dai" (high), "chu" (middle) and "sho" (low), each of which is further separated into 'senior' and 'junior' ("gon"))

sen.j: 7級 大僧都
sen.e: Seventh rank: Dai (high) sozu (the second highest ranking Buddhist priest position, further divided into three ranks, "dai" (high), "chu" (middle), and "sho" (low), each of which is further separated into 'senior' and 'junior' ("gon"))
sen.cmt: 「僧都」の訳には、bishopとすることもできますが、そうすると、律師を特定することができず、結局、ここでは、僧階のイメージが訳出できれば良いものと判断し、規則的にランク付けされている僧階をできるだけ、英語で表現しました。
sen.e: Seventh rank: Dai (high) sozu (the second-highest ranking Buddhist priest position, further divided into three ranks, "dai" (high), "chu" (middle) and "sho" (low), each of which is further separated into "senior" and "junior" ("gon"))

Seventh rank: Dai (high) sozu (the second-highest ranking Buddhist priest position, further divided into three ranks, "dai" (high), "chu" (middle) and "sho" (low), each of which is further separated into "senior" and "junior" ("gon"))

sen.j: 8級 権大僧都
sen.e: Eighth rank: Gon (junior) dai sozu
Eighth rank: Gon (junior) dai sozu
Eighth rank: Gon (junior) dai sozu

sen.e: Ninth rank: Chu (middle) sozu
Ninth rank: Chu (middle) sozu
Ninth rank: Chu (middle) sozu

sen.e: Tenth rank: Gon chu sozu
Tenth rank: Gon chu sozu

sen.j: 11級 少僧都
sen.e: Eleventh rank: Sho (low) sozu

sen.j: 12級 権小僧都
sen.e: Twelfth rank: Gon sho sozu
Twelfth rank: Gon sho sozu
Twelfth rank: Gon sho sozu

sen.j: 13級 大律師
sen.e: Thirteenth rank: Dai risshi (the third highest ranking Buddhist priest position, further divided into three ranks, "dai" (senior), none (middle), and "gon" (junior))
Thirteenth rank: Dai risshi (the third-highest ranking Buddhist priest position, further divided into three ranks, "dai" (senior), "none" (middle) and "gon" (junior))

Fourteenth rank: Risshi

sen.e: Fifteen rank: Gon (junior) risshi
Fifteen rank: Gon (junior) risshi
Fifteen rank: Gon (junior) risshi

sen.j: 権大僧都その他の僧階は細則による。
sen.e: Priests ranked "Gon dai sozu" or lower are subject to bylaws.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外処理 （１）原文に合わせて訳しました。
sen.e: Priests ranked "Gon dai sozu" or lower are subject to bylaws.
Priests ranked Gon dai sozu or lower are subject to bylaws.

sen.j: （権大僧都は、真言宗各派経営の大学卒業者と細則の該当者。）
sen.e: Priests ranked "Gon dai sozu" have to be a graduate from a university run by a school of Shingon Sect.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外処理 （２）原文に合わせて訳しました。
sen.e: A priest ranked "Gon dai sozu" must be a graduate of a university run by a school of the Shingon sect.
A priest ranked Gon dai sozu must be a graduate of a university run by a school of the Shingon sect.

sen.j: 教階（主教・弘教・示教・司教・補教）
sen.e: Kyokai (hierarchy of teaching priests) (shukyo/kokyo/shikyo/shikyo/hokyo)
sen.cmt: 「主教」や「司教」などは、bishipと訳すことができますが、他のものとの統一が図れないため、その訳は採用しませんでした。また、それぞれの違いを訳出ための根拠を見つけることができませんでした。
sen.e: Kyokai (hierarchy of teaching priests) (shukyo; kokyo; shikyo; shikyo; hokyo)
Kyokai (hierarchy of teaching priests) (shukyo; kokyo; shikyo; shikyo; hokyo)

sen.j: 住職（得度と度牒を受け、四度加行の後、伝法灌頂に入壇。練行を行った者。)
sen.e: Chief priest: priests who entered into Buddhist priesthood, received a Docho (government document certifying that they are Buddhist priests or nuns), went through Shidokegyo (four types of training), had a denpo-kanjo (ritual in which the Dharma is transferred to a pupil), and completed Rengyo (training of esoteric Buddhism).

Chief priest: A priest who has entered the Buddhist priesthood, received a Docho (government document certifying that he/she is a Buddhist priest or nun), gone through Shidokegyo (four types of training), had a denpo-kanjo (ritual in which the Dharma is transferred to a pupil), and completed Rengyo (training in Esoteric Buddhism)

Chief priest: A priest who has entered the Buddhist priesthood, received a Docho (government document certifying that he/she is a Buddhist priest or nun), gone through Shidokegyo (four types of training), had a denpo-kanjo (ritual in which the Dharma is transferred to a pupil), and completed Rengyo (training in Esoteric Buddhism)

sen.j: 教師（僧侶で教師の補任された者。
sen.e: Teacher (priests designated as a teacher
Teacher (priests designated as teachers
Teacher (priests designated as teachers

sen.j: 教師に補任されることが、住職の就任条件でもある。）
sen.e: To become a chief priest, one has to be designated as a teacher.
To become a chief priest, one has to be designated as a teacher.
To become a chief priest, one has to be designated as a teacher.)

sen.j: 布教師教階（輔教・司教・示教・弘教・主教） また、（教師の研鑽と補任のために）教学審議会を開催する。
sen.e: Kyogaku shingikai (educational council) is held (to encourage teachers to study and to select teachers from priests).
sen.cmt: 日本語の意味が読み取れません。後半部分のみ訳させていただきます。
sen.e: Kyogaku shingikai (educational council) is held (to encourage teachers to study, and to select teachers from priests)
Kyogaku shingikai (educational council) is held (to encourage teachers to study, and to select teachers from priests)

February 15: Joraku-e (anniversary of Buddha's death)
